Election Law (French Electoral Procedure.perspective_relevance: As an expert in French electoral procedures and election law, I bring deep knowledge of the constitutional mechanisms for dissolving the National Assembly, the legal and practical limits on snap elections, and the historical frequency and political calculus involved. I can assess both the legal triggers and the political incentives/disincentives, particularly in chaotic or deadlocked situations like the current one.
Election Law (French Electoral Procedure.status_quo: No snap election is called; the current deadlocked legislature continues with frequent government changes, making do with fragile, minority or temporary governments until the next scheduled legislative election.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Constitutional Constraint: One-Year Waiting Period
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The French Constitution (Article 12) forbids a new dissolution of the National Assembly within one year of the previous one. Since the last dissolution was in June/July 2024, a new snap election cannot legally be called before mid-2025, narrowing the window to the last six months of the year.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate of Snap Elections in the Fifth Republic
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Historically, snap dissolutions are rare; only six since 1958, and never twice in such short succession. Presidents are wary of using this tool, especially after being politically burned by a previous dissolution.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Political Incentives and Macron’s Calculus
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Macron’s 2024 dissolution backfired spectacularly, weakening his bloc and empowering both the left and the far right. News articles report widespread public opposition to another dissolution (over 60% against in recent polling), and Macron himself has admitted the previous call was an error. Barring complete paralysis, he will be reluctant to call again.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Parliamentary Fragmentation and Chronic Government Instability
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability (moderately). The current Assembly is exceptionally unstable: Five prime ministers in two years, routine no-confidence votes, and no bloc anywhere near a majority. This ongoing instability could make government formation or budget approval impossible, increasing pressure for another dissolution as a last resort.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: External Pressures: Budget Crisis, Social Unrest, Economic Deterioration
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability (slightly). Mounting fiscal pressures (debt >110% of GDP, failed austerity budgets), ratings downgrades, and large-scale strikes could push the situation from chronic instability to outright crisis, potentially making a new election the only way out.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Opposition Incentives and Threats
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral to slight increase. The National Rally and some left factions are calling for new elections, but the mainstream left and public opinion are against. Macron is unlikely to move unless forced by absolute necessity.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Imminent Presidential Election (2027) and Macron’s Legacy
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Macron cannot run again in 2027 and would not want to further damage his legacy or empower his enemies. The risk of another dissolution strengthening the far right or left is high, making caution more likely.

Election Law (French Electoral Procedure.no_scenario: Despite ongoing instability, Macron continues to appoint short-lived minority governments, using technocrats or centrists to muddle through. Budgets are passed via compromise or Article 49.3 (forcing bills through), and while there is gridlock and unrest, the Assembly is not dissolved again before January 1, 2026. Macron chooses to avoid another risky dissolution, especially given public opposition and his own weakened position.
Election Law (French Electoral Procedure.yes_scenario: The political deadlock becomes unmanageable: the government cannot pass any budget, and repeated no-confidence votes topple every prime minister. Social unrest escalates, financial markets panic, and the EU threatens sanctions over fiscal non-compliance. Macron, facing both internal and external crisis, judges that only fresh elections can restore legitimacy, and—despite the risks—calls a snap election in late 2025 as the least-worst option.
Election Law (French Electoral Procedure.final_reasoning: The legal window for a new dissolution is narrow (mid-2025 to January 1, 2026). The base rate for two dissolutions in such quick succession is extremely low, and Macron has strong personal, political, and constitutional incentives NOT to call another snap election. Public opinion is strongly against it, and his party was badly damaged by the last one. However, the level of instability is historically high: five PMs in less than two years, repeated budget crises, and no stable majority. If a full-blown governmental paralysis or fiscal/economic emergency develops (e.g., inability to pass a budget, EU sanctions, major social unrest), Macron might feel compelled to dissolve again as a last resort, but this remains a tail risk. Considering all factors—including the historic reluctance to use dissolution, the self-inflicted damage from the previous snap election, and the possibility of muddling through—I assess the probability of Macron calling another snap legislative election before January 1, 2026 as low, but not negligible, given the extraordinary context.

Election Law (Constitutional Law Article.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Election Law with a focus on Constitutional Law Article 12, I am well-positioned to assess both the legal and procedural constraints governing snap dissolutions of the French National Assembly. My expertise allows me to evaluate the interplay between constitutional doctrine (notably the one-year minimum between dissolutions), political precedent, and the incentives/disincentives for Macron to trigger another snap election in the current volatile context.
Election Law (Constitutional Law Article.status_quo: No further snap legislative election is called by Macron before January 1, 2026. The National Assembly remains deadlocked, with governments forming and falling but Macron refraining from another dissolution.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Constitutional Constraint (Article 12 One-Year Rule)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability; Article 12 prohibits another dissolution within one year of the last, so a snap election could only be called after July 2025. This narrows the window for action to about 6 months and makes Macron less likely to exercise the option except as a last resort.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent Precedent and Public Backlash
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability; Macron's 2024 dissolution is widely viewed as a political error, with recent polling showing 62% of the French public oppose another early election before 2027. The negative reception creates a strong political disincentive to dissolve again.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Ongoing Parliamentary Instability
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability; Persistent government collapse—five prime ministers in two years, repeated no-confidence votes, and inability to pass budgets—raises the possibility that Macron views dissolution as the only escape from gridlock.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Opposition Incentives and Pressure
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability; Both far-right (Le Pen) and far-left (Mélenchon) camps are agitating for another election, hoping to capitalize on Macron's unpopularity. If these forces unite in paralyzing the government, the pressure on Macron grows.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Macron's Political Incentives and Legacy Considerations
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability; Macron's term ends in 2027 and his personal popularity is at a historic low. Another dissolution could risk further strengthening the opposition and undermining his legacy. He may prefer to muddle through with caretaker/minority governments.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate of Snap Dissolutions in the Fifth Republic
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability; Snap dissolutions are rare in the Fifth Republic, especially two within 18 months. The base rate for consecutive dissolutions in such a short span is extremely low (last occurred in the 1950s-60s).

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Imminent Budget and Economic Crisis
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability; The inability to pass a budget and growing economic crisis (debt at 114% of GDP, Fitch downgrade, risk of IMF/ECB intervention) could force Macron's hand if government paralysis threatens financial stability.

Election Law (Constitutional Law Article.no_scenario: Despite ongoing parliamentary chaos and repeated government collapses, Macron withstands pressure to dissolve, instead appointing technocratic or minority governments that limp through to 2026, perhaps using Article 49.3 or other constitutional tools to pass budgets. Public and elite opinion remains hostile to another snap election, and Macron calculates that dissolution would only worsen instability or further empower the far right/left. No dissolution is called before January 1, 2026.
Election Law (Constitutional Law Article.yes_scenario: The National Assembly remains ungovernable: repeated no-confidence votes topple successive prime ministers, and no coalition can pass the 2026 budget. Mounting protests, financial markets reacting to the crisis, and the threat of EU sanctions/IMF intervention convince Macron that dissolution is the only escape from paralysis. In late 2025, after the constitutional one-year limit lapses, Macron dissolves the Assembly and calls a new snap election, hoping to break the deadlock.
Election Law (Constitutional Law Article.final_reasoning: The legal window for Macron to dissolve the Assembly again only opened in July 2025, leaving a very narrow period (July-December 2025) for a snap election to be called. Since the last dissolution was broadly unpopular and is now considered a political error, Macron faces strong disincentives to repeat it, especially as polling shows the public overwhelmingly opposes another early election. The base rate of two dissolutions in such rapid succession is extremely low in the Fifth Republic. However, the current level of political instability is unprecedented: five prime ministers in two years, repeated budget impasses, and a looming fiscal crisis. The government is surviving week-to-week, and the opposition is highly mobilized. If the new government falls again or is unable to pass a legally required budget by year's end, Macron might feel compelled to dissolve as a last resort to avert a constitutional, political, or financial meltdown. We are in a regime of abnormal, high-variance outcomes, but the structural constraints and Macron's incentives still lean toward muddling through rather than risking another dissolution. On balance, I judge a snap election call before January 1, 2026 as possible but more likely than not to be avoided, with the probability somewhat elevated by the extreme instability and budget crises.

Political Risk Analysis (Scenario Planni.perspective_relevance: As a political risk analyst specializing in scenario planning, I focus on institutional constraints, actor incentives, and the structural features of political systems. This enables me to weigh the likelihood of high-impact, low-probability events (such as another snap election) against the inertia of established democratic norms and the historical frequency of such events (base rates), drawing on both recent developments and the deeper logic of French Fifth Republic politics.
Political Risk Analysis (Scenario Planni.status_quo: President Macron does not call another snap legislative election before 2026. While government instability persists, the constitutional default is to muddle through with fragile or minority governments until the next scheduled election cycle.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Constitutional Constraint on Dissolutions
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The French constitution only allows one dissolution per year, and the most recent one was in July 2024. Macron now has the legal ability to call another snap election, but this tool is normatively reserved for moments of total gridlock or crisis; repeated dissolutions are rare and risky.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Historical Base Rates
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Since the founding of the Fifth Republic, repeat snap elections within a single presidential term are extremely rare. Most presidents prefer to avoid them due to the risk of further destabilization and backlash.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Current Political Instability / Government Deadlock
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. The Assembly is deeply fragmented, no stable government has emerged, and frequent no-confidence votes have toppled multiple prime ministers. This raises the chance Macron could seek a reset if the situation becomes ungovernable.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Macron's Incentives and Political Calculus
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mixed effect. Macron is personally weakened (popularity at historic lows), and the last dissolution backfired, strengthening his opponents. He may be reluctant to risk another, but if faced with total paralysis or a constitutional crisis, he could see dissolution as a lesser evil.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Public and Elite Backlash to Repeated Dissolutions
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Recent polling (Odysseus Institute for Le Figaro, June 2025) shows over 60% of French citizens oppose another dissolution before the next presidential election. Elites and the public view repeated dissolutions as destabilizing and illegitimate.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Opposition Pressures and Calls for New Elections
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Marginally increases probability. Both the far-right (Le Pen) and the far-left have openly called for new elections, seeking to capitalize on the government's weakness. Macron may face mounting pressure if no government can survive.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Economic Crisis and Social Unrest
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Strikes, mass protests, rising debt, and market jitters could create a sense of emergency, making another snap election appear as a necessary step to restore legitimacy.

Political Risk Analysis (Scenario Planni.no_scenario: Despite ongoing instability and fragile governments, Macron avoids calling another snap election. Instead, he cycles through technocratic or caretaker prime ministers, muddles through budget crises, and relies on ad hoc majorities and Article 49.3 to pass bare-minimum legislation. The opposition continues to agitate, but Macron and the political elite fear that another dissolution would worsen the crisis, further delegitimize the regime, and possibly hand power to the extremes. The status quo of stalemate and public discontent holds until the next scheduled elections.
Political Risk Analysis (Scenario Planni.yes_scenario: Political and fiscal paralysis escalates: the new prime minister (Lecornu or successor) cannot pass a budget, repeated no-confidence votes topple successive governments, and strikes or market panic force Macron's hand. With no majority willing to take responsibility for austerity or reform, and pressure from both the street and the opposition mounting, Macron concludes that another snap election is the least bad option to break the deadlock and restore legitimacy—even at the risk of a far-right or far-left breakthrough.
Political Risk Analysis (Scenario Planni.final_reasoning: The structural and historical base rates for repeat snap legislative elections in France are extremely low: under the Fifth Republic, dissolutions are rare, and repeated dissolutions within a single presidential term are almost unprecedented. Macron's personal and political incentives argue against a new election; his popularity is at rock bottom, and the last snap election further fragmented the Assembly and weakened his position. Public opinion is firmly against another dissolution, and political elites view a repeat as a sign of regime breakdown. However, the current situation is unusually unstable: five prime ministers in under two years, persistent budget crises, mass protests, and the inability to form a working government. France's debt and deficit issues, international market pressure, and the risk of a constitutional or financial crisis keep open the possibility that Macron may be compelled to act if all other options fail. On balance, scenario analysis suggests the status quo (no new election) is still the most likely outcome, given institutional inertia, public opposition, and Macron's own risk aversion. But the probability is materially elevated compared to normal French politics, given the scale of the crisis. My final probability is therefore higher than the historical base rate, but not extreme: about a 30% chance that Macron calls another snap legislative election before 2026.

Political Risk Analysis (Crisis Decision.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Political Risk Analysis (Crisis Decisionmaking Models), my approach brings structured scenario analysis, attention to base rates, and a focus on how leaders behave under crisis and uncertainty. I assess structural constraints (constitutional rules, time lags), political incentives (risk/reward calculus for Macron), coalition dynamics, and public sentiment, while weighting the inertia of institutions and the status quo bias observed in most political systems.
Political Risk Analysis (Crisis Decision.status_quo: Macron has already called one snap legislative election (July 2024), creating a highly fragmented parliament with three main blocs and no clear majority. The constitution prohibits another dissolution before July 2025 (one year after the last), which has now passed. Despite the instability, the default is for Macron to attempt government formation through appointing successive prime ministers or seeking ad hoc majorities, rather than another dissolution.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Constitutional Constraints and Precedent
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The French constitution allows only one dissolution per year, and snap elections are rare; the last two were in 1997 and 2024. Historically, French presidents avoid multiple dissolutions due to political risk and diminishing returns.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Political Instability and Government Turnover
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. France has seen five prime ministers in two years and repeated no-confidence votes. Persistent deadlock, inability to pass budgets, and pressure from both left and right for a reset could push Macron toward another dissolution.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Public Opinion Backlash and Electoral Risk
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Polls show a strong majority of French voters oppose another dissolution before the 2027 presidential election. Macron’s previous snap election is viewed negatively, making him risk-averse to further electoral gambles unless absolutely necessary.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Political Incentives and Macron's Legacy
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Ambiguous. Macron may wish to avoid being seen as paralyzed, but a second snap election could further empower the extremes and damage his legacy. If a government can limp along, he may prefer to focus on foreign policy until 2027.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: External and Economic Pressure
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Marginally increases probability if crisis deepens. Market panic, ratings downgrades, or inability to pass a budget could force Macron’s hand, but this would require the situation to deteriorate further.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Opposition Maneuvering
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Marginally increases probability. Both Le Pen and Mélenchon are calling for new elections, and continued no-confidence votes could create a tipping point. However, unless Macron calculates he can win or at least stabilize the situation, he is less likely to move.

Political Risk Analysis (Crisis Decision.no_scenario: Despite ongoing government instability, Macron continues to appoint new prime ministers or forms caretaker governments that survive via tactical alliances or abstentions. The various blocs tolerate a stalemate, preferring to avoid elections that could further empower their rivals. Macron avoids another dissolution due to public backlash and risk to his coalition, focusing on incremental governance and international issues until 2026.
Political Risk Analysis (Crisis Decision.yes_scenario: A major political or fiscal crisis erupts—e.g., failure to pass a critical budget, financial market turmoil, mass resignations, or a successful and repeated series of no-confidence votes—leaving no viable government able to command even a minimal working majority. Macron, unable to form any stable government and facing mounting domestic and international pressure, calls another snap legislative election in a last-ditch effort to break the deadlock before 2026.
Political Risk Analysis (Crisis Decision.final_reasoning: Base rates and constitutional precedent strongly favor the status quo—French presidents are highly reluctant to call multiple snap elections in one term, and the public is overwhelmingly opposed. Macron’s first snap election backfired, and current polls show all parties are likely to remain fragmented, with the risk of further empowering the far-right or left. However, the extraordinary instability (five PMs in two years, repeated no-confidence votes, mass protests) is unprecedented even by French standards. The government’s persistent inability to pass a budget or maintain a PM for more than a few months raises the risk of gridlock so acute that dissolution becomes the lesser evil. Still, unless a true crisis of governance or markets erupts, Macron’s incentives and the status quo bias point toward muddling through. I estimate the probability at 28%, higher than the historical base rate, but still reflecting the significant friction against a second dissolution in such a short period.

Political Science (Rational Choice Theor.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Political Science with a focus on Rational Choice Theory, my perspective is uniquely suited to assess the likelihood of another snap legislative election by analyzing the incentives, constraints, and payoff structures facing President Macron and key political actors. Rational Choice Theory emphasizes that leaders make decisions to maximize their utility (political survival, legacy, policy outcomes) while weighing risks and expected costs. In highly fragmented and unstable environments like France's current political landscape, these calculations become central to predicting high-stakes moves such as assembly dissolution.
Political Science (Rational Choice Theor.status_quo: The status quo is continued government instability, frequent changes of prime minister, and a hung parliament with three blocs (left, center, far-right), but no dissolution or snap election called by Macron since July 2024.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Constitutional Constraint (One-year Rule)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Macron cannot dissolve the Assembly until at least July 2025, and with only a few months left after that until the resolution deadline, the window for action is very narrow.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Political Backlash from Previous Snap Election
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The 2024 snap election is widely seen as a political blunder, with polling and media showing strong public opposition (over 60% against another dissolution) and a sense that Macron’s authority has been further weakened.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate of Snap Elections in France
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Historically, snap dissolutions of the National Assembly are rare—especially two in a single presidential term. The last two snap dissolutions (1997, 2024) were separated by decades.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Parliamentary Deadlock and Government Instability
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. France has cycled through at least five prime ministers in two years, with repeated government collapses and ongoing threats of no-confidence votes. The inability to pass budgets and growing protest activity heightens crisis pressure.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Macron’s Incentives (Rational Choice)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Macron is highly unlikely to gamble again after being burned in 2024—the rational strategy is to avoid further destabilizing his administration unless total paralysis or an external shock forces his hand.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Opposition Pressure (Le Pen, Left, Strikes)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral to slightly increases probability. While Le Pen and the left demand new elections, Macron’s rational response is to resist unless he calculates the risk of inaction (total ungovernability) exceeds the risk of a new loss.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: International and Economic Constraints
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. France faces high debt, market pressure, and the risk of external shocks; a snap election would spook markets further and could compromise France’s position in the EU and globally.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Impeachment or Macron Ceasing to be President
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. If Macron is removed or resigns before 2026, the question resolves NO by definition. No signs suggest this is imminent, but rising instability introduces a nonzero risk.

Political Science (Rational Choice Theor.no_scenario: Despite persistent instability, Macron appoints new technocratic or compromise governments as needed, muddling through with minority support and tactical concessions until the constitutional deadline passes. He resists opposition calls for dissolution, hoping to avoid further losses and public backlash, and instead focuses on foreign policy and crisis management. No snap election is called before January 1, 2026.
Political Science (Rational Choice Theor.yes_scenario: Political deadlock intensifies—multiple failed governments, inability to pass a budget, massive protests, and perhaps a constitutional crisis (e.g., a government unable to form or function at all). Macron, calculating that he has no viable alternative and that the costs of inaction now exceed the risks of another snap election, dissolves the Assembly in late 2025 in a last-ditch effort to restore governability.
Political Science (Rational Choice Theor.final_reasoning: Rational Choice Theory predicts leaders act to maximize survival and minimize risk. Macron’s last snap election backfired badly, and both public opinion and historical precedent argue against another dissolution so soon. While the level of instability is unprecedented—multiple PMs, near-constant threats of no confidence, and ungovernability—the rational move for Macron is to muddle through, appoint compromise figures, and avoid a move that would almost certainly end his political relevance and further empower his rivals. The window for legal dissolution is short (from July to December 2025), and even severe instability can likely be managed with temporary governments and concessions. While a total system breakdown could force Macron’s hand, this is a low-probability scenario within the remaining timeframe. Thus, while not impossible, the base rate and current incentives suggest a clear lean toward NO.

Political Science (Coalition Theory).perspective_relevance: As a Political Science expert specializing in coalition theory, I can assess both the formal constitutional constraints and the practical incentives/disincentives for dissolving parliament in a fragmented assembly. I’m equipped to analyze unstable coalition dynamics, executive-legislative relations, and the calculus presidents use when facing persistent deadlock.
Political Science (Coalition Theory).status_quo: France is governed by a highly unstable minority/coalition government, with no bloc holding a majority, frequent changes of prime minister, and recurrent no-confidence votes. Macron has not called another snap election since July 2024.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: French constitutional restriction (cannot dissolve within a year of the last dissolution)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability, as Macron’s options are legally constrained until July 2025 (now elapsed, so this restriction is lifted as of September 2025, but this delayed possible dissolution).

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Severe legislative deadlock and repeated government collapses
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability, since persistent inability to form a stable government is a classic trigger for dissolution under coalition theory.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Public and elite backlash to previous snap election (per polling and media)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability, as evidence shows strong public resistance (over 60%) to another dissolution so soon, raising political costs for Macron.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Macron’s personal incentives and legacy concerns
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: Macron’s popularity is at historic lows, and a new election could further empower the far-right or left, making a snap election risky for his legacy and his party’s parliamentary standing.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Opposition strategy (calls for dissolution by RN and Le Pen)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability: If opposition can credibly threaten paralyzing gridlock, Macron may see dissolution as a lesser evil, but this is mitigated by risk of RN gains.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Budget impasses and risk of government shutdown
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability: Failure to pass the budget, repeated no-confidence votes, and inability to govern increase pressure for a new election as a last resort solution.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Coalition alternatives (possibility of technical, caretaker or cohabitation governments)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: As long as some form of technocratic or caretaker government can function (even weakly), the president may avoid dissolution.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base rate of multiple dissolutions in France within a single presidential term
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: Under the Fifth Republic, multiple dissolutions in such quick succession are rare; presidents typically avoid repeated dissolutions due to the risk of diminishing returns and legitimacy.

Political Science (Coalition Theory).no_scenario: Despite ongoing deadlock, Macron cobbles together a caretaker or technocratic government, relies on Article 49.3 to pass budgets, or simply muddles through with rotating prime ministers, banking on public exhaustion and elite resistance to another election. The fear of further empowering the National Rally and the negative public mood toward more elections persuade Macron to avoid another dissolution until his term ends or the next scheduled elections.
Political Science (Coalition Theory).yes_scenario: After yet another government collapse (e.g., Lecornu falls to a successful no-confidence motion), and with the budget stalled or the Assembly refusing to cooperate on basic governance, Macron concludes that no stable government is possible. Facing worsening economic crisis, market jitters, and mounting street protests, he gambles on a snap election, hoping to reconfigure the Assembly—even knowing the risk of greater gains for the opposition.
Political Science (Coalition Theory).final_reasoning: Coalition theory suggests that dissolution is most likely when (1) deadlock is total, (2) no coalition or technocratic government is viable, and (3) the executive faces existential or legitimacy pressures greater than the risks of an election. In France, while the Assembly is extremely fragmented and the government has collapsed repeatedly, Macron faces major constraints: public opinion is overwhelmingly against another dissolution, his own popularity is dismal, and the far-right stands to gain most from new elections. The Fifth Republic’s base rate for back-to-back dissolutions is very low: only a handful in 65 years, and never two within 18 months. Macron’s incentives are to avoid further empowering RN or the radical left and instead limp along with technical governments, even at the cost of legislative paralysis. The news points to recurrent government instability, but also to a high level of elite and public resistance to further snap elections, and no clear sign that Macron is preparing to dissolve again. Thus, while the situation is volatile and the probability is elevated compared to a typical year, the barriers to another dissolution before 2026 remain substantial. I assess the probability at 22%, above the historical base rate but well below even odds.

Political Science (French SemiPresidenti.perspective_relevance: As an expert in French SemiPresidentialism, I can dissect the constitutional powers available to the President, the dynamics of executive-legislative relations, and historical precedents of dissolution in the Fifth Republic. My expertise allows me to weigh formal mechanisms (like Article 12 of the Constitution) and informal norms, the practical consequences of deadlock, and the political calculus facing Macron in a divided Assembly. I can also reference base rates for legislative dissolutions and analyze how French political actors tend to behave under instability.
Political Science (French SemiPresidenti.status_quo: No snap legislative election is called before 2026. The government continues to muddle through, with shifting prime ministers and fragile coalitions, but Macron does not dissolve the Assembly again before the constitutional window closes.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Constitutional Constraint (One-year rule)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Snap elections cannot be called until at least July 2025, so the available window is now short (Oct–Dec 2025). There is little precedent for back-to-back dissolutions within such a short period, and Macron may be reluctant to trigger further instability so soon after the last dissolution.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Political Deadlock and Government Instability
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Five PMs in two years and repeated government collapses signal extreme instability. If the Lecornu government also falls or cannot pass a budget, Macron may seek a new mandate to break the impasse.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Public and Elite Backlash Against Dissolution
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Recent surveys show strong public opposition to another dissolution (62% against), and elites may advise caution after the political cost of the last snap election.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Opposition Pressure and Calls for Dissolution
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. The far-right (RN/Le Pen) and some far-left figures are openly calling for new elections to take advantage of the government’s weakness.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Macron’s Strategic Calculus
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Macron’s previous dissolution backfired, and his popularity is at a record low (15%). He may judge that another election would strengthen his opponents further and weaken his legacy.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Budget and Fiscal Crisis
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability. Persistent failure to pass a budget, combined with market jitters and EU pressure, may force Macron’s hand if all other options are exhausted.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate of Dissolutions Under the Fifth Republic
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Dissolutions are rare (five in 65+ years), and no president has called two in one term. The base rate is low.

Political Science (French SemiPresidenti.no_scenario: Despite continued instability and fragile governments, Macron avoids calling another snap election. Instead, he cycles through technocratic or caretaker prime ministers, relies on ad hoc coalitions, or uses constitutional tools (like Article 49.3) to push through essential legislation. The Assembly limps along until 2026, with no clear majority but also no dissolution.
Political Science (French SemiPresidenti.yes_scenario: The Lecornu government collapses (e.g., budget defeat, no-confidence vote). Macron, after exhausting attempts to form an alternative government, concludes that dissolution is the only way to break the deadlock. Despite the risks, he dissolves the Assembly in late 2025, hoping to clarify the parliamentary situation, even with the likelihood of further fragmentation or opposition gains.
Political Science (French SemiPresidenti.final_reasoning: France is experiencing historic instability: five prime ministers in two years, repeated no-confidence votes, and a budget crisis. The Fifth Republic’s semi-presidential system gives Macron the constitutional power to dissolve the Assembly, but only once every 12 months. That window has just reopened (since July 2025), but public and elite backlash after the last dissolution is substantial, and Macron is politically weakened. The base rate for dissolutions is very low, and there is no precedent for two dissolutions in such rapid succession. Macron’s previous snap election backfired, costing his bloc seats, and current polling/elite sentiment suggests a new election would likely strengthen the RN and left, not the center. However, the government is extremely fragile: if Lecornu falls and no stable government can be formed, Macron may be forced to act—especially if the budget crisis deepens and markets/EU pressure mount. On balance, while the structural incentives for a new dissolution are rising, the strong public/elite aversion to another snap election, the base rate, and Macron’s own political caution make it more likely that he will muddle through until 2026, unless a total impasse leaves him with no alternative. Given these cross-currents, I assess the probability as moderately low but not negligible.

Comparative Politics (ExecutiveLegislati.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Comparative Politics, specifically in Executive-Legislative Relations, I bring to bear knowledge about French constitutional mechanisms, executive-legislative bargaining, parliamentary dissolution triggers, cohabitation dynamics, and the incentives presidents face when managing fractured legislatures. This expertise is critical for assessing the likelihood that Macron will use his constitutional prerogative to dissolve the National Assembly and call snap elections, particularly given the present deadlock, instability, and public sentiment.
Comparative Politics (ExecutiveLegislati.status_quo: No snap election is called before 2026. The government continues to limp along with a fragile/unstable minority government, frequent changes of Prime Minister, and ongoing parliamentary deadlock, but the Assembly is not dissolved again before January 1, 2026.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: French constitutional rules on dissolution
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The constitution only allows one dissolution per year, so with the last dissolution in July 2024, the earliest possible date for another is July 2025, leaving a narrow window before January 2026. Presidents are typically reluctant to overuse this tool due to the political risks and historical precedent.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Parliamentary fragmentation and government instability
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. The Assembly remains split three ways, and France has had five prime ministers in under two years, with repeated budget crises and multiple successful no-confidence votes. This level of instability raises the likelihood that the president may use his dissolution power to break deadlock.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Public and elite opinion on snap elections
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Polls and news coverage (e.g., the June 2025 Odysseus/Le Figaro survey) show strong public opposition to another dissolution so soon, and Macron’s previous snap election is widely regarded as a political error. This makes another snap election unpopular and politically risky.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Macron’s own political incentives and legacy
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mixed. Macron’s authority is weakened, and another snap election could further erode his legitimacy if it backfires. However, if government paralysis becomes unmanageable (e.g., failed budgets, inability to govern), he may see dissolution as the lesser evil, especially if he can blame parliament for dysfunction.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Opposition party strategies
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. The far-right National Rally and some Left parties are actively calling for dissolution, hoping to capitalize on government unpopularity and win a stronger mandate. This creates pressure on Macron, especially if a new government falls again.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base rate of snap elections in France
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Historically, snap dissolutions are rare. Under the Fifth Republic, most Assemblies serve out their full term or are only dissolved once per presidential mandate. Multiple dissolutions in quick succession are extremely uncommon.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Economic and social crisis severity
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Large-scale strikes, budget crises, and potential ratings downgrades are ongoing. If the state cannot pass a budget or faces a genuine crisis of governance, the practical necessity of restoring order might push Macron toward dissolution despite risks.

Comparative Politics (ExecutiveLegislati.no_scenario: Despite continued instability, Macron and his team cobble together temporary coalitions to pass essential legislation, or simply govern weakly via decrees and procedural maneuvers. The opposition continues to call for new elections, but public opposition and fear of strengthening the far right deter Macron from dissolving the Assembly again. The government muddles through until at least January 2026.
Comparative Politics (ExecutiveLegislati.yes_scenario: Parliamentary deadlock intensifies: a new government falls (possibly Lecornu), the Assembly repeatedly rejects budgets, and mass protests or social unrest escalate. Macron concludes that the only way to break the logjam is to dissolve the Assembly again, calling a snap election in late 2025 to try and clarify the political mandate and restore governability.
Comparative Politics (ExecutiveLegislati.final_reasoning: While the current French political crisis is unusually severe, the status quo of muddling through with unstable minority governments is resilient. The French constitution, political norms, and especially the negative public reaction to the 2024 dissolution weigh heavily against another snap election in such a short time. The base rate for double dissolutions within 18 months is extremely low under the Fifth Republic. However, the unprecedented nature of the present crisis (record government turnover, legislative deadlock, mass protests, and inability to pass budgets) does increase the risk. Opposition pressure, particularly from the RN and the left, and the threat of an ungovernable state, mean that a new dissolution is not out of the question. Still, Macron is likely to exhaust all other options (repeated new PMs, deals with opposition, governing by decree) before resorting to another dissolution, given the high political risks and low public support. I therefore judge the probability to be higher than the historical base rate, but still less likely than not.

Comparative Politics (Government Stabili.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Comparative Politics (Government Stability Models), my perspective is crucial for forecasting government dissolution and snap elections. I bring to bear cross-national data on parliamentary deadlock, minority government survival rates, executive-legislative relations, and the specific institutional mechanisms of the French Fifth Republic, including the president's constitutional power to dissolve the legislature and historic patterns of its use. I also integrate quantitative models that weight status quo bias, historical base rates, and the impact of economic, fiscal, and protest-induced instability on executive calculus.
Comparative Politics (Government Stabili.status_quo: The status quo is continued parliamentary instability with repeated no-confidence motions, minority cabinets, and high protest activity, but without Macron calling another snap legislative election before 2026. Macron repeatedly appoints new prime ministers or cobbles together temporary support to avoid dissolution.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base rate of snap election calls under the French Fifth Republic
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Since 1958, dissolutions have been rare (only 5 times, most recently 2024, and never twice in a single presidential term). The constitutional one-year waiting period after a dissolution (July 2024-July 2025) is almost over, but repeat dissolutions in rapid succession are historically unprecedented.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Current degree of parliamentary fragmentation and instability
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. France has had 5 PMs in 21 months, repeated government collapses, and no stable majority. The government is facing persistent no-confidence threats, fiscal crisis, and mass protests, which increase the risk of executive recourse to dissolution.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Macron's personal incentives and political capital
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Macron's previous snap election (2024) backfired, strengthening both the left and far-right and further fragmenting parliament. Public opinion is strongly against another dissolution (over 60% oppose per polls). Macron risks further damaging his legacy and his party's prospects if he dissolves again.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Institutional constraints and alternatives to dissolution
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The president can continue to rotate technocratic or cross-partisan PMs, or allow minority governments to limp on using Article 49.3 (forcing passage of budgets). With only months left before the 2026 scheduled election, the bar for dissolution is high.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: External triggers: budgetary crisis, EU/IMF pressure, or mass protest escalation
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. If the government is unable to pass a budget, faces market panic, or mass unrest escalates beyond control, Macron may judge that only a new parliamentary mandate can restore governability—even if the risks are high.

Comparative Politics (Government Stabili.no_scenario: Despite persistent instability, Macron avoids calling new elections. He appoints technocratic or compromise PMs (like Lecornu), who patch together temporary majorities or simply survive repeated no-confidence motions. Article 49.3 is used to pass budgets. Protest and opposition continue, but the political system muddles through to the regularly scheduled 2026 elections.
Comparative Politics (Government Stabili.yes_scenario: A government collapse coincides with a failed budget, market panic, and/or mass protests that paralyze the country (e.g., 'Bloquons tout!' general strike or violent unrest). Macron concludes that government is unworkable, all coalition-building efforts have failed, and with his back against the wall, he uses his constitutional power to dissolve the Assembly and call snap elections before January 1, 2026.
Comparative Politics (Government Stabili.final_reasoning: Base rates strongly favor the status quo: dissolutions are rare and never repeated so quickly. Macron has strong incentives not to call another snap election, given his previous experience and overwhelming public opposition. The fragmented parliament and government instability do raise the risk, but so far, the government has muddled through with rotating PMs and use of Article 49.3. Even now, there are ongoing efforts to cut deals with the Socialists and patch together a working majority, and the PM is scheduled to meet with key opposition leaders in the coming days. The window for dissolution is closing, with only three months left, and Macron, facing a hostile electorate and no guarantee of a more governable parliament, is likely to avoid further destabilization. However, the risk is not zero—if a full-scale budgetary or social crisis erupts and public order is threatened, Macron could be forced to call elections. Weighing all factors, and especially the historical rarity of repeat dissolutions and the very strong status quo bias in executive action under the Fifth Republic, I assign a probability of 18%.

French Studies (Fifth Republic Constitut.perspective_relevance: My expertise in French Studies, especially constitutional analysis of the Fifth Republic, is highly relevant because the question hinges on both the political calculus of President Macron and the constitutional mechanics governing the dissolution of the National Assembly. The 1958 Constitution gives the president significant discretion, but only under specific political-institutional circumstances, and the current environment of instability, past precedent, and constitutional limitations all bear directly on the forecast.
French Studies (Fifth Republic Constitut.status_quo: No further snap election is called before 2026. Instead, Macron continues to cycle through prime ministers and minority cabinets, relying on compromise, ad hoc alliances, and constitutional mechanisms to survive until the next scheduled legislative elections.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Constitutional Constraints and Precedent
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The Fifth Republic’s Article 12 allows the president to dissolve the Assembly, but only once per year. Macron used this power in June 2024, so he cannot call another dissolution until July 2025. Historically, dissolutions are rare (six times since 1958), and a second dissolution in such close succession is unprecedented and would be seen as a constitutional last resort.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Parliamentary Deadlock and Government Instability
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. The current Assembly is highly fragmented, with five prime ministers in two years and persistent inability to pass budgets or maintain majority support. Votes of no confidence have toppled multiple prime ministers. This level of instability puts real pressure on Macron to seek a solution, with dissolution as a constitutional safety valve.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Political and Public Backlash Against Dissolution
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Recent polling and public discourse indicate strong opposition to another snap election. 62% reject a new dissolution before 2027, and Macron's last dissolution is now widely seen as a political blunder that deepened the crisis. Calling another dissolution could further erode legitimacy and risk backlash.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Macron’s Personal Incentives and Political Calculus
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Ambiguous, but leans toward decreasing probability. Macron has little to gain from another dissolution: polls suggest no bloc would win a governing majority, and the National Rally could gain further. Macron’s approval is at record lows, and he likely wants to avoid triggering a scenario that could hasten the rise of the opposition or further diminish his power.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Pressure from Opposition and Social Unrest
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability. The left and far right continue to threaten censure motions, and the RN in particular is openly calling for dissolution. Widespread strikes, protests, and budget impasses increase the risk of a total breakdown, which could push Macron to call elections if no government can hold for even a short period.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rates and Historical Practice
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases probability. Since 1958, dissolving the Assembly twice within two years has never happened. Presidents overwhelmingly try to avoid repeated dissolutions and instead seek technocratic solutions, minority governments, or compromise.

French Studies (Fifth Republic Constitut.no_scenario: Despite ongoing instability and repeated government collapses, Macron continues to appoint new prime ministers, shifting policy and negotiating ad hoc support to pass budgets. The Assembly remains unruly, but no single crisis is acute enough to force immediate dissolution. Macron, chastened by public backlash and the risks of another snap election, chooses to muddle through until 2026, even at the cost of further weakening his presidency.
French Studies (Fifth Republic Constitut.yes_scenario: Parliamentary deadlock worsens: the next budget fails completely, no prime minister can secure or retain a majority, and a series of no-confidence motions make government formation impossible. Social unrest escalates into a crisis of order, or a financial shock (such as ratings downgrades or eurozone intervention) makes the status quo untenable. Faced with total paralysis and explicit calls from all blocs for new elections, Macron invokes Article 12 and dissolves the Assembly—accepting the political risks as necessary to restore some form of government.
French Studies (Fifth Republic Constitut.final_reasoning: The constitutional mechanism is available after July 2025, and the level of political instability is extraordinary, with a historically unprecedented turnover of prime ministers, repeated failed budgets, and persistent social unrest. However, the base rate for repeated dissolutions is extremely low, and both historical precedent and public opinion are heavily against another snap election. Macron himself is politically weakened, and the likely outcome of a new election would not break the deadlock but could empower his opponents further. French presidents under the Fifth Republic have almost always avoided repeated dissolutions, preferring to manage through technocratic cabinets or minority governments. While the probability is higher than in a normal year due to the extreme instability, the strong institutional and political incentives against another dissolution in such a short window mean the status quo—no further snap election—remains the most likely outcome. Therefore, I assign a probability of 25%.
